Description of the Bombe |year=1988 |url=http://www.ellsbury.com/bombe2.htm |accessdate=1 May 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101152256/http://www.ellsbury.com/bombe2.htm |archive-date=1 January 2011 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} At its peak, GC&CS was reading approximately 4,000 messages per day.{{Citation |last=Carter |first=Frank |title=The Turing Bombe |journal=The Rutherford Journal |url=http://www.rutherfordjournal.org/article030108.html |issn=1177-1380 |access-date=26 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727230547/http://www.rutherfordjournal.org/article030108.html |archive-date=27 July 2011 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} As a hedge against enemy attack{{Citation |title=Bletchley Park Jewels |chapter=Outstations from the Park |url=http://www.mkheritage.co.uk/bpt/outstations/outstations.htm |accessdate=16 April 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091213164632/http://www.mkheritage.co.uk/bpt/Outstations/Outstations.htm |archive-date=13 December 2009 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} most bombes were dispersed to installations at [[Adstock]] and [[Wavendon]] (both later supplanted by installations at [[Stanmore]] and [[Eastcote]]), and [[Gayhurst]].{{Citation |last=Toms |first=Susan |title=Enigma and the Eastcote connection |year=2005 |url=http://www.ruislip.co.uk/eastcotemod/enigma.htm |accessdate=16 April 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204105055/http://www.ruislip.co.uk/eastcotemod/enigma.htm |archive-date=4 December 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{Harvnb|Welchman|1997|p=141}} [[Luftwaffe]] messages were the first to be read in quantity. The German navy had much tighter procedures, and the capture of code books was needed before they could be broken. When, in February 1942, the German navy introduced the four-rotor Enigma for communications with its Atlantic U-boats, this traffic became unreadable for a period of ten months.{{Harvnb|Smith|2006|p=34}} Britain produced modified bombes, but it was the success of the [[US Navy Bombe|US Navy bombe]] that was the main source of reading messages from this version of Enigma for the rest of the war. Messages were sent to and fro across the Atlantic by enciphered teleprinter links. [[File:Colossus.jpg|thumbnail|right|A Mark 2 Colossus computer. The ten Colossi were the world's first (semi-) programmable electronic computers, the first having been built in 1943]] The [[Cryptanalysis of the Lorenz cipher|Lorenz messages]] were codenamed ''Tunny'' at Bletchley Park. They were only sent in quantity from mid-1942. The Tunny networks were used for high-level messages between German High Command and field commanders. With the help of German operator errors, the cryptanalysts in the [[Testery]] (named after [[Ralph Tester]], its head) worked out the logical structure of the machine despite not knowing its physical form. They devised automatic machinery to help with decryption, which culminated in [[Colossus computer|Colossus]], the world's first programmable digital electronic computer. This was designed and built by [[Tommy Flowers]] and his team at the [[Post Office Research Station]] at [[Dollis Hill]]. The prototype first worked in December 1943, was delivered to Bletchley Park in January and first worked operationally on 5 February 1944. Enhancements were developed for the Mark 2 Colossus, the first of which was working at Bletchley Park on the morning of 1 June in time for [[Normandy landings|D-day]]. Flowers then produced one Colossus a month for the rest of the war, making a total of ten with an eleventh part-built. The machines were operated mainly by Wrens in a section named the [[Newmanry]] after its head [[Max Newman]].{{Harvnb|Good|Michie|Timms|1945|p=276}} Bletchley's work was essential to defeating the [[U-boat]]s in the [[Battle of the Atlantic]], and to the British naval victories in the [[Battle of Cape Matapan]] and the [[Battle of North Cape]]. In 1941, Ultra exerted a powerful effect on the [[North African Campaign|North African desert campaign]] against German forces under General [[Erwin Rommel]]. General Sir [[Claude Auchinleck]] wrote that were it not for Ultra, "Rommel would have certainly got through to Cairo". While not changing the events, "[[Ultra (cryptography)|Ultra]]" decrypts featured prominently in the story of [[Operation Salaam|Operation SALAM]], [[László Almásy]]'s mission across [[Western Desert (Egypt)|the desert]] behind Allied lines in 1942.Gross, Kuno, Michael Rolke and András Zboray, [http://fjexpeditions.com/resources/salam/operation_salam.htm Operation SALAM] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516121757/http://fjexpeditions.com/resources/salam/operation_salam.htm |date=16 May 2013 }} - László Almásy’s most daring Mission in the Desert War, Belleville, München, 2013 Prior to the [[Normandy landings]] on D-Day in June 1944, the Allies knew the locations of all but two of Germany's fifty-eight Western-front divisions.{{Harvnb|Hinsley|Stripp|1993|p=9}} {{clear left}} ===Italian signals=== {{see also|Cryptanalysis of the Enigma}} Italian signals had been of interest since Italy's attack on Abyssinia in 1935. During the [[Spanish Civil War]] the [[Royal Italian Navy|Italian Navy]] used the K model of the commercial Enigma without a plugboard; this was solved by Knox in 1937. When Italy entered the war in 1940 an improved version of the machine was used, though little traffic was sent by it and there were "wholesale changes" in Italian codes and cyphers.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=lwKuAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT87&dq=Bletchley+%22Italian+Navy%22+%22K+model%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-uPS7lYPeAhXMC8AKHUeqD-wQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Bletchley%20%22Italian%20Navy%22%20%22K%20model%22&f=false|title=The Bletchley Park Codebreakers|first= Michael|last= Smith|publisher=Biteback|year=2011|isbn=978-1849540780}} Knox was given a new section for work on Enigma variations, which he staffed with women ("Dilly's girls"), who included [[Margaret Rock]], Jean Perrin, Clare Harding, Rachel Ronald, Elisabeth Granger; and [[Mavis Batey|Mavis Lever]].{{Harvnb|Grey|2012|pp=1323–3}} Mavis Lever solved the signals revealing the Italian Navy's operational plans before the [[Battle of Cape Matapan]] in 1941, leading to a British victory.{{Citation |last=Batey |first=Mavis | author-link = Mavis Batey |title=Breaking Italian Naval Enigma |year=2011 |page=81}} in {{Harvnb|Erskine|Smith|2011|pp=79–92}} Although most Bletchley staff did not know the results of their work, Admiral [[Andrew Cunningham, 1st Viscount Cunningham of Hyndhope|Cunningham]] visited Bletchley in person a few weeks later to congratulate them. On entering World War II in June 1940, the [[Italy|Italians]] were using book codes for most of their military messages. The exception was the [[Italian Navy]], which after the Battle of Cape Matapan started using the [[C-38 (cipher machine)|C-38]] version of the [[Boris Hagelin]] [[Rotor machine|rotor-based]] [[cipher machine]], particularly to route their navy and merchant marine convoys to the conflict in North Africa.{{Citation |last=Hinsley |first=Sir Harry | author-link = Harry Hinsley |title=The Influence of ULTRA in the Second World War |origyear=1993 |year=1996 |url=http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/research/security/Historical/hinsley.html |accessdate=23 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120706194507/http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/research/security/Historical/hinsley.html |archivedate=6 July 2012}} Transcript of a lecture given on Tuesday 19 October 1993 at Cambridge University As a consequence, [[James Ramsay Montagu Butler|JRM Butler]] recruited his former student [[Bernard Willson]] to join a team with two others in Hut{{nbsp}}4.{{Citation |last=Dakin |first=Alec Naylor |year=1993 |title=The Z Watch in Hut 4, Part I }} in {{Harvnb|Hinsley|Stripp|1993|pp=50{{ndash}}56}}{{Citation |last=Wilkinson |first=Patrick |year=1993 |title=Italian naval ciphers}} in {{Harvnb|Hinsley|Stripp|1993|pp=61–67}} In June 1941, Willson became the first of the team to decode the Hagelin system, thus enabling military commanders to direct the [[Royal Navy]] and [[Royal Air Force]] to sink enemy ships carrying supplies from Europe to Rommel's [[Afrika Korps]]. This led to increased shipping losses and, from reading the intercepted traffic, the team learnt that between May and September 1941 the stock of fuel for the [[Luftwaffe]] in North Africa reduced by 90 percent.{{cite web |url=http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/content/archive/index/july1941.rhtm |title=July 1941 |publisher=Bletchley Park |accessdate=23 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117213633/http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/content/archive/index/july1941.rhtm |archive-date=17 January 2013 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} After an intensive language course, in March 1944 Willson switched to Japanese language-based codes.{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} A Middle East Intelligence Centre (MEIC) was set up in Cairo in 1939. When Italy entered the war in June 1940, delays in forwarding intercepts to Bletchley via congested radio links resulted in cryptanalysts being sent to Cairo. A Combined Bureau Middle East (CBME) was set up in November, though the Middle East authorities made "increasingly bitter complaints" that [[GC&CS]] was giving too little priority to work on Italian cyphers. However, the principle of concentrating high-grade cryptanalysis at Bletchley was maintained.[[Harry Hinsley|Hinsley, Harry]] ''British Intelligence in the Second World War, Volume One: Its Influence on Strategy and Operations'' (1979, Her Majesties Stationery Office, London) pp. 191{{ndash}}221, 570{{ndash}}72 {{ISBN|0 11 630933 4}} [[John Chadwick]] started cryptanalysis work in 1942 on Italian signals at the naval base 'HMS Nile' in Alexandria. Later, he was with GC&CS; in the Heliopolis Museum, Cairo and then in the Villa Laurens, Alexandria.[http://www.classics.cam.ac.uk/faculty/research_groups_and_societies/mycenaean_epigraphy/decipherment/life_of_chadwick/ "Life of John Chadwick : 1920 - 1998 : Classical Philologist, Lexicographer and Co-decipherer of Linear B"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101017230923/http://www.classics.cam.ac.uk/faculty/research_groups_and_societies/mycenaean_epigraphy/decipherment/life_of_chadwick/ |date=2010-10-17 }}, Faculty of Classics, Cambridge University ===Soviet signals=== Soviet signals had been studied since the 1920s. In 1939{{ndash}}40, [[John Tiltman]] (who had worked on Russian Army traffic from 1930) set up two Russian sections at Wavendon (a country house near Bletchley) and at [[Sarafand al-Amar|Sarafand]] in Palestine. Two Russian high-grade army and navy systems were broken early in 1940. Tiltman spent two weeks in Finland, where he obtained Russian traffic from Finland and Estonia in exchange for radio equipment. In June 1941, when the Soviet Union became an ally, Churchill ordered a halt to intelligence operations against it. In December 1941, the Russian section was closed down, but in late summer 1943 or late 1944, a small GC&CS Russian cypher section was set up in London overlooking Park Lane, then in Sloane Square.{{Citation |last=Smith |first=Michael | author-link = Michael Smith (newspaper reporter) |title=The Government Code and Cypher School and the First Cold War |year=2011 |pages=13–34}} in {{Harvnb|Erskine|Smith|2011}} ===Japanese signals=== An outpost of the Government Code and Cypher School had been set up in Hong Kong in 1935, the [[Far East Combined Bureau]] (FECB). The FECB naval staff moved in 1940 to Singapore, then [[Colombo]], [[Sri Lanka|Ceylon]], then [[Kilindini Harbour|Kilindini]], [[Mombasa]], Kenya. They succeeded in deciphering Japanese codes with a mixture of skill and good fortune.{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Michael |title=Mombasa was base for high-level UK espionage operation |url=http://www.coastweek.com/codes.htm |work=coastweek.com |publisher=Coastweek |accessdate=20 June 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515123737/http://www.coastweek.com/codes.htm |archive-date=15 May 2013 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} The Army and Air Force staff went from Singapore to the [[Wireless Experimental Centre]] at [[Delhi]], India.{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=54-55, 175-180}} In early 1942, a six-month crash course in Japanese, for 20 undergraduates from Oxford and Cambridge, was started by the Inter-Services Special Intelligence School in Bedford, in a building across from the main Post Office. This course was repeated every six months until war's end. Most of those completing these courses worked on decoding Japanese naval messages in [[Hut 7]], under [[John Tiltman]]. By mid-1945, well over 100 personnel were involved with this operation, which co-operated closely with the FECB and the US Signal intelligence Service at [[Arlington Hall]], Virginia. In 1999, Michael Smith wrote that: "Only now are the British codebreakers (like [[John Tiltman]], [[Hugh Foss]], and [[Eric Nave]]) beginning to receive the recognition they deserve for breaking Japanese codes and cyphers".{{Harvnb|Smith|2001|pp=127{{ndash}}51}} ==Post war== ===Continued secrecy=== After the War, the secrecy imposed on Bletchley staff remained in force, so that most relatives never knew more than that a child, spouse, or parent had done some kind of secret war work.{{Harvnb|Hill|2004|pp=129{{ndash}}35}} Churchill referred to the Bletchley staff as "the geese that laid the golden eggs and never cackled".{{Harvnb|Lewin|2001|p=64}} That said, occasional mentions of the work performed at Bletchley Park slipped the censor's net and appeared in print.{{Harvnb|Thirsk|2008|pp=61–68}} With the publication of [[F. W. Winterbotham|F.{{nbsp}}W. Winterbotham's]] ''The Ultra Secret'' (1974){{Citation |last=Winterbotham |first=F. W. | author-link = F.W. Winterbotham |title=The Ultra Secret |place=London |publisher=Weidenfeld & Nicolson |year=1974}} public discussion of Bletchley's work finally became possible (though even today some former staff still consider themselves bound to silence){{Citation |last=Withers-Green |first=Sheila |title=audiopause audio: I made a promise that I wouldn't say anything |year=2010 |url=http://audioboo.fm/boos/176850-i-made-a-promise-that-i-wouldn-t-say-anything-sheila-withers-green-bpark2010?playlist_direction=forward |accessdate=15 July 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008045611/http://audioboo.fm/boos/176850-i-made-a-promise-that-i-wouldn-t-say-anything-sheila-withers-green-bpark2010?playlist_direction=forward |archive-date=8 October 2011 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} and in July 2009 the British government announced that Bletchley personnel would be recognised with a commemorative badge.{{citation |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/5789263/Enigma-codebreakers-to-be-honoured-finally.html |title=Enigma codebreakers to be honoured finally |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |access-date=3 April 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180809120446/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/5789263/Enigma-codebreakers-to-be-honoured-finally.html |archive-date=9 August 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} ===Site=== After the war, the site passed through a succession of hands{{cite web|url=http://www.bellaonline.com/articles/art9678.asp|title=Solo Travel Summer Home Preparation|website=Bellaonline.com|accessdate=25 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311205544/http://bellaonline.com/articles/art9678.asp|archive-date=11 March 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} and saw a number of uses, including as a teacher-training college and local [[General Post Office|GPO]] headquarters. By 1991, the site was nearly empty and the buildings were at risk of demolition for redevelopment.{{cite web|url=https://bletchleypark.org.uk/our-story/why-it-matters/preserving-bletchley-park|title=Preserving Bletchley Park|publisher=Bletchley Park|accessdate=13 October 2018}} In February 1992, the [[Milton Keynes Borough Council]] declared most of the Park a conservation area, and the Bletchley Park Trust was formed to maintain the site as a museum. The site opened to visitors in 1993, and was formally inaugurated by HRH The Duke of Kent as Chief Patron in July 1994. In 1999 the land owners, the [[Office of Government Commerce|Property Advisors to the Civil Estate]] and [[BT Group|BT]], granted a lease the Trust giving the Trust control over most of the site.{{cite web|url=http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/content/hist/recent.rhtm|title=Bletchley Park History|author=Bletchley Park Trust.|website=Bletchleypark.org.uk|accessdate=25 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102204518/http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/content/hist/recent.rhtm|archive-date=2 January 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ==Heritage attraction== [[File:Turing flat.jpg|right|thumb|The stableyard cottages, where Alan Turing worked]] June 2014 saw the completion of an £8 million restoration project, which was marked by a visit from [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge]]. The Duchess' paternal grandmother, Valerie, and Valerie's twin sister, Mary (née Glassborow), both worked at Bletchley Park during the war. The twin sisters worked as Foreign Office Civilians in [[Hut 6]], where they managed the interception of enemy and neutral diplomatic signals for decryption. Valerie married Catherine's grandfather, Captain [[Family of Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Peter Middleton]].{{cite web |title=Valerie Glassborow, Bletchley Park Veteran and Grandmother of HRH The Duchess of Cambridge |url=https://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/news/v.rhtm/Valerie_Glassborow_Bletchley_Park_Veteran_and_Grandmother_of_HRH_The_Duchess_of_Cambridge-834327.html |publisher=BletchleyPark.org.uk |accessdate=30 September 2015 |date=17 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001013632/https://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/news/v.rhtm/Valerie_Glassborow_Bletchley_Park_Veteran_and_Grandmother_of_HRH_The_Duchess_of_Cambridge-834327.html |archive-date=1 October 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/06/18/code-me-kate-british-royal-opens-museum-at-restored-wwii-deciphering-center/|title=Code me, Kate: British royal opens museum at restored WWII deciphering center, Bletchley Park|work=Fox News|accessdate=25 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151006152006/http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/06/18/code-me-kate-british-royal-opens-museum-at-restored-wwii-deciphering-center/|archive-date=6 October 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-27898997|title=Duchess of Cambridge opens Bletchley Park restored centre|work=BBC News|accessdate=25 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151015152823/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-27898997|archive-date=15 October 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ===Exhibitions=== [[File:Bombe-rebuild.jpg|thumb|Rear of the rebuilt [[Bombe]]{{Citation |last=Harper |first=John |title=Bombe Rebuild Project |year=2008 |url=http://www.jharper.demon.co.uk/bombe1.htm |accessdate=24 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131204202741/http://www.jharper.demon.co.uk/bombe1.htm |archivedate=4 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}]] * Block C Visitor Centre ** Secrets Revealed introduction ** The Road to Bletchley Park. Codebreaking in World War One. ** Intel Security Cybersecurity exhibition. Online security and privacy in the 21st Century. * Block B ** Operational Bombe Rebuild ** Lorenz Cipher ** Alan Turing ** Enigma machines ** Japanese codes ** Home Front exhibition. How people lived in WW2 * The Mansion ** Office of Alistair Denniston ** Library. Dressed as a World War II naval intelligence office ** The Imitation Game exhibition ** Gordon Welchman: Architect of Ultra Intelligence exhibition * Huts 3 and 6. Codebreaking offices as they would have looked during World War II. * Hut 8. ** Interactive exhibitions explaining codebreaking ** Alan Turing's office ** Pigeon exhibition. The use of pigeons in World War II. * Hut 11. Life as a WRNS Bombe operator * Hut 12. Bletchley Park: Rescued and Restored. Items found during the restoration work. * Wartime garages * Hut 19. 2366 Bletchley Park Air Training Corp Squadron ===Learning Department=== [[File:StoryOfEnigma.jpg|thumb|The Story of Enigma workshop with [[Middlesex University]] students]] The Bletchley Park Learning Department offers educational group visits with active learning activities for schools and universities. Visits can be booked in advance during term time, where students can engage with the history of Bletchley Park and understand its wider relevance for computer history and national security. Their workshops cover introductions to codebreaking, cyber security and the story of [[Enigma machine|Enigma]] and [[Lorenz cipher|Lorenz]].{{cite web|title=Bletchley Park|url=https://bletchleypark.org.uk/learn|accessdate=8 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180308231532/https://bletchleypark.org.uk/learn|archive-date=8 March 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ==Funding== In October 2005, American billionaire [[Sidney Frank]] donated £500,000 to Bletchley Park Trust to fund a new Science Centre dedicated to [[Alan Turing]].[http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/news/docview.rhtm/274566 Action This Day] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060320002438/http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/news/docview.rhtm/274566 |date=20 March 2006 }}, Bletchley Park News, 28 February 2006 [[Simon Greenish]] joined as Director in 2006 to lead the fund-raising effort{{cite book| last1=Greenish | first1=Simon | authorlink1=Simon Greenish | last2=Bowen | first2=Jonathan | authorlink2=Jonathan Bowen | last3=Copeland | first3=Jack | authorlink3=Jack Copeland | year=2017 | chapter=Chapter 19 – Turing's monument | editor-last1=Copeland | editor-first1=Jack |editorlink1=Jack Copeland | editor2=et al. | title=[[The Turing Guide]] | pages=189–196 }} in a post he held until 2012 when Iain Standen took over the leadership role.{{cite web | url=http://codemanship.co.uk/parlezuml/blog/?postid=1081 | title=New Bletchley Park CEO, And A Tribute To Simon Greenish | website=codemanship.co.uk | publisher=codemanship | location=UK | first=Jason | last=Gorman | date=16 January 2012 | accessdate=24 January 2018 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125015439/http://codemanship.co.uk/parlezuml/blog/?postid=1081 | archive-date=25 January 2018 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }} In July 2008, a letter to ''[[The Times]]'' from more than a hundred academics condemned the neglect of the site.{{citation |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/letters/article4385384.ece |title=Saving the heritage of Bletchley Park (Letter) |work=[[The Times]] |access-date=26 July 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809164121/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/letters/article4385384.ece |archive-date=9 August 2011 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7517874.stm "Neglect of Bletchley condemned"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090930042236/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7517874.stm |date=30 September 2009 }}, [[BBC News]]. In September 2008, [[Pretty Good Privacy|PGP]], [[IBM]], and other technology firms announced a fund-raising campaign to repair the facility.{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-10034884-83.html|title=PGP, IBM help Bletchley Park raise funds|author=Tom Espiner|date=8 September 2008|publisher=CBS Interactive|work=CNET|accessdate=25 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104020636/http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-10034884-83.html|archive-date=4 November 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} On 6 November 2008 it was announced that [[English Heritage]] would donate £300,000 to help maintain the buildings at Bletchley Park, and that they were in discussions regarding the donation of a further £600,000.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7710966.stm "New lifeline for Bletchley Park"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906182932/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7710966.stm |date=6 September 2009 }}, [[BBC News]]. In October 2011, the Bletchley Park Trust received a £4.6m [[Heritage Lottery Fund]] grant to be used "to complete the restoration of the site, and to tell its story to the highest modern standards" on the condition that £1.7m of 'match funding' is raised by the Bletchley Park Trust.{{citation |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-15171726 |title=Bletchley Park wins #pound;4.6m Heritage Lottery Fund grant |work=BBC News |date=5 October 2011 |access-date=21 June 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160720165131/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-15171726 |archive-date=20 July 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{Citation |title=It’s Happening!: The Long-Awaited Restoration of Historic Bletchley Park |publisher=Bletchley Park Trust |url=http://www.bletchleypark.org/content/contact/donation/support.rhtm |accessdate=7 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104230748/http://www.bletchleypark.org/content/contact/donation/support.rhtm |archivedate=4 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Just weeks later, Google contributed £550k{{Citation |title=Google gives £550k to Bletchley Park |publisher=The Register |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/12/15/google_give_half_a_mill_to_computer_museum/ |access-date=10 August 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810171938/https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/12/15/google_give_half_a_mill_to_computer_museum/ |archive-date=10 August 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} and by June 2012 the trust had successfully raised £2.4m to unlock the grants to restore Huts 3 and 6, as well as develop its exhibition centre in Block C.{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/06/27/bletchley_park_raises_7_million|title=Bletchley Park gets £7.4m to tart up WWII code-breaking huts|website=Theregister.co.uk|accessdate=25 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308100313/http://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/06/27/bletchley_park_raises_7_million/|archive-date=8 March 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Additional income is raised by renting Block H to the National Museum of Computing, and some office space in various parts of the park to private firms.{{Citation|title=BPSIC: Bletchley Park Science and Innovation Centre|url=http://www.bpsic.com/|website=Bpsic.com|accessdate=30 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130122205819/http://www.bpsic.com/#|archive-date=22 January 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |title=Bletchley Park Science and Innovation Centre |publisher=Bletchley Park Trust |url=http://www.bletchleypark.org/commercial.rhtm |website=Bletchleypark.org |accessdate=30 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528083112/http://www.bletchleypark.org/commercial.rhtm |archivedate=28 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |title=Bletchley Park Science and Innovation Centre |url=http://www.bpsic.com/index.html |website=Bpsic.com |accessdate=7 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708090316/http://www.bpsic.com/index.html |archivedate=8 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} ==Other organisations sharing the campus== ===The National Museum of Computing=== {{main|The National Museum of Computing}} [[File:ColossusRebuild 11.jpg|thumb|right|[[Anthony Sale|Tony Sale]] supervising the breaking of an enciphered message with the completed [[Colossus computer]] rebuild in 2006]] The National Museum of Computing is housed in Block H, which is rented from the Bletchley Park Trust. Its Colossus and Tunny galleries tell an important part of allied breaking of German codes during World War II. There is a working reconstruction of a [[Colossus computer]] that was used on the high-level [[Lorenz cipher]], codenamed ''Tunny'' by the British.{{cite web|url=http://www.codesandciphers.org.uk/lorenz/rebuild.htm|title=Colossus Rebuild - Tony Sale|website=Codesandciphers.org.uk|accessdate=25 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322000440/http://www.codesandciphers.org.uk/lorenz/rebuild.htm|archive-date=22 March 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/06/29/geeks_guide_tnmoc/|title=Rise of the machines, south of Milton Keynes|publisher=The Register|accessdate=25 February 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180126100029/http://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/06/29/geeks_guide_tnmoc/|archive-date=26 January 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The museum, which opened in 2007, is an independent voluntary organisation that is governed by its own board of trustees. Its aim is "To collect and restore computer systems particularly those developed in Britain and to enable people to explore that collection for inspiration, learning and enjoyment."{{Citation |title=Mission Statement of The National Museum of Computing |publisher=CodesandCiphers Heritage Trust |url=http://www.tnmoc.org/about-us |accessdate=8 April 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214103752/http://www.tnmoc.org/about-us |archive-date=14 February 2014 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Through its many exhibits, the museum displays the story of computing through the mainframes of the 1960s and 1970s, and the rise of personal computing in the 1980s. It has a policy of having as many of the exhibits as possible in full working order.{{cite web|url=http://www.tnmoc.org/special-projects/harwell-dekatron-witch/restoration|title=Restoration|publisher=National Museum of Computing|accessdate=13 October 2018}} The Colossus and Tunny galleries are open daily. The rest of the museum is open to the public every Thursday, Saturday and Sunday afternoons and most bank holidays, and by appointment for groups only, at other times. There are guided tours on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons and Thursday morning. There is a modest admission charge to the museum to help cover overheads.{{cite web|url=http://www.tnmoc.org/about-us/contact-national-museum-computing?gclid=Cj0KCQjwr4beBRDNARIsAGZaZ5daUCjUO-GVHwheSxIqCb3iur8O5XDK94jvr9tPs1gtgqm5q3ShDX8aAiaEEALw_wcB|title=About us|publisher=National Museum of Computing|accessdate=13 October 2018}} ===National College of Cyber Security=== The museum is working with four other organisations, in a group called Qufaro, to create the new college for students between 16 and 19 years of age. It will be located in Block G which was being renovated in 2017 with funding from the Bletchley Park Science and Innovation Centre. (Bletchley Park Trust has no involvement with the college.) The [[National College of Cyber Security]] is scheduled to open in 2018.{{cite web |url=https://www.museumsassociation.org/museums-journal/news/30112016-national-museum-of-computing-involved-in-setting-up-cyber-security-training-college |title=National Museum of Computing involved in setting up cyber security college |publisher=Museums Association |date=30 November 2016 |accessdate=13 May 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170811073537/http://www.museumsassociation.org/museums-journal/news/30112016-national-museum-of-computing-involved-in-setting-up-cyber-security-training-college |archive-date=11 August 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |author=Eleanor Ross |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/nov/24/college-of-national-security-teenage-codebreakers-school-open-bletchley-park |title=School for teenage codebreakers to open in Bletchley Park | Technology |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=12 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161213072011/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/nov/24/college-of-national-security-teenage-codebreakers-school-open-bletchley-park |archive-date=13 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/uks-first-cybersecurity-college-open-historic-bletchley-park-1593212 |title=UK's first National College of Cyber Security to open at historic Bletchley Park |website=Ibtimes.co.uk |date=24 November 2016 |accessdate=12 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220112506/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/uks-first-cybersecurity-college-open-historic-bletchley-park-1593212 |archive-date=20 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |author=Tom Mendelsohn |url=https://arstechnica.com/business/2016/11/cyber-college-wannabe-codebreakers-earmarked-bletchley-park-site/ |title=Cyber college for wannabe codebreakers planned at UK’s iconic Bletchley Park |publisher=Ars Technica |date=25 November 2016 |accessdate=12 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161213215637/http://arstechnica.com/business/2016/11/cyber-college-wannabe-codebreakers-earmarked-bletchley-park-site/ |archive-date=13 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} ===RSGB National Radio Centre=== The [[Radio Society of Great Britain]]'s National Radio Centre (including a library, radio station, museum and bookshop) are in a newly constructed building close to the main Bletchley Park entrance.{{Citation |title=National Radio Centre Official Opening |journal=RadCom |date=August 2012 |volume=88 |issue=8 |page=12 |publisher=[[Radio Society of Great Britain]]}}{{cite journal |journal=QST |publisher=The [[American Radio Relay League]] |date=October 2012 |volume=96 |issue=10 |page=96 |author=David Summer, K1ZZ |title=RSGB opens showcase for amateur radio at Bletchley Park}} ==Location== Bletchley Park is opposite [[Bletchley railway station]]. It is close to junctions 13 and 14 of the [[M1 motorway|M1]]. Located {{convert|50|mi|km}} northwest of [[London]].{{cite web|url=https://bletchleypark.org.uk/|title=Welcome|publisher=Bletchley Park|accessdate=13 October 2018}} ==In popular culture== [[File:BletcleyPark SubModel.JPG|thumb|German [[U-boat]] model used in the film ''[[Enigma (movie)|Enigma]]'' (2001)]] [[File:Sunbeam Talbot 2 litre Sports Tourer 1947.jpg|thumb|The Sunbeam-Talbot 2-litre used in the film ''[[Enigma (movie)|Enigma]]'' (2001)]] ===Film=== * The film ''[[Enigma (2001 film)|Enigma]]'' (2001), starring [[Kate Winslet]], [[Saffron Burrows]] and [[Dougray Scott]], is set in part in Bletchley Park.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0157583/|title=Enigma|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=13 October 2018}} * The film ''[[The Imitation Game]]'' (2014), starring [[Benedict Cumberbatch]] as [[Alan Turing]], is set in Bletchley Park, and was partially filmed there.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2084970/|title=The Imitation Game|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=13 October 2018}} ===Literature=== * Bletchley featured heavily in [[Robert Harris (novelist)|Robert Harris]]' novel ''[[Enigma (novel)|Enigma]]'' (1995).{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/11/books/an-enigma-wrapped-in-a-mystery.html|title=An Enigma Wrapped in a Mystery|year=1995|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=13 October 2018}} * A fictionalised version of Bletchley Park is featured in [[Neal Stephenson]]'s novel ''[[Cryptonomicon]]'' (1999).{{cite web|url=http://www.locusmag.com/1999/Issues/08/Stephenson.html |title=Neal Stephenson: Cryptomancer|publisher=[[Locus (magazine)|Locus]]|date=1 August 1999|accessdate=13 October 2018}} * Bletchley Park plays a significant role in [[Connie Willis]]' novel ''[[All Clear]]'' (2010).{{cite web|url=https://io9.gizmodo.com/5711667/the-troubles-with-time-travel-in-connie-willis-all-clear|title=The troubles with time travel in Connie Willis' All Clear|date=10 December 2010|publisher=Gizmodo|accessdate=13 October 2018}} * The Agatha Christie novel ''[[N or M?]]'', published in 1941, was about codebreaking during the Second World War and featured a character called Major Bletchley. Although the book had nothing to do with Bletchley Park, having been written when the purpose of the site was still secret, Christie herself was almost arrested under the belief that the character name and subject matter were a hint to Germany that something was happening there. It turned out to be a coincidence.{{Citation|title=Agatha Christie was investigated by MI5 over Bletchley Park mystery|author=Richard Norton-Taylor|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/feb/04/agatha-christie-mi5-bletchley|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=4 February 2013|accessdate=29 March 2013}} ===Radio=== * The Radio Show ''[[Hut 33]]'' is a [[Situation Comedy]] set in the fictional 33rd Hut of Bletchley Park.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007r8hg|title=Hut 33|publisher=BBC|accessdate=30 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119080457/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007r8hg|archive-date=19 November 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} * The [[Big Finish Productions]] ''[[Doctor Who]]'' audio ''Criss-Cross'', released in September 2015, features the [[Sixth Doctor]] working undercover in Bletchley Park to decode a series of strange alien signals that have hindered his [[TARDIS]], the audio also depicting his first meeting with his new companion Constance Clarke.{{cite web|url=https://www.bigfinish.com/releases/v/criss-cross-876|title=Criss-Cross|publisher=Big Finish|accessdate=13 October 2018}} * The Bletchley Park Podcast began in August 2012, with new episodes being released approximately monthly. It features stories told by the codebreakers, staff and volunteers, audio from events and reports on the development of Bletchley Park.{{cite web|url=https://audioboom.com/channel/bletchley-park|title=Bletchley Park|publisher=Audioboom|accessdate=13 October 2018}} ===Television=== * The 1979 ITV television serial ''[[Danger UXB]]'' featured the character Steven Mount, who was a codebreaker at Bletchley and was driven to a [[nervous breakdown]] (and eventual suicide) by the stressful and repetitive nature of the work.{{cite web|url=https://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/books/188561/Review-Danger-UXB-The-Heroic-Story-of-the-WWII-Bomb-Disposal-Teams|title=Review: Danger UXB - The Heroic Story of the WWII Bomb Disposal Teams|date=23 July 2010|publisher=Daily Express|accessdate=13 October 2018}} * In ''[[Foyle's War]]'', Adam Wainwright ([[Foyle's War#Samantha Stewart|Samantha Stewart]]'s fiancé, then husband), is a former Bletchley Park codebreaker.{{cite web |website=foyleswar.com |url=http://www.foyleswar.com/the-official-foyles-war-blog/honeysuckle-weeks-describes-life-the-foyle |title=Honeysuckle Weeks describes life on the Foyle's War set |date=13 August 2013 |access-date=11 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151114070444/http://www.foyleswar.com/the-official-foyles-war-blog/honeysuckle-weeks-describes-life-the-foyle |archive-date=14 November 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |website=foyleswar.com |title=Bios: Adam Wainwright |url=http://www.foyleswar.com/foyles-war-characters/adam-wainwright |access-date=11 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151107084438/http://www.foyleswar.com/foyles-war-characters/adam-wainwright |archive-date=7 November 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |work=Daily Mail |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2293305/Honeysuckle-Weeks-opens-diary-share-secrets-set-new-series-Foyles-War--including-bizarre-offer-star-Michael-Kitchen-.html |title=Honeysuckle Weeks opens her diary to share her secrets from the set of the new series of Foyle's War - including a bizarre offer for co-star Michael Kitchen... |date=15 March 2013 |access-date=11 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119164330/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2293305/Honeysuckle-Weeks-opens-diary-share-secrets-set-new-series-Foyles-War--including-bizarre-offer-star-Michael-Kitchen-.html |archive-date=19 November 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} * The Second World War code-breaking sitcom pilot "Satsuma & Pumpkin" was recorded at Bletchley Park in 2003 and featured [[Bob Monkhouse]], OBE in his last ever screen role. The BBC declined to produce the show and develop it further before creating effectively the same show on [[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]] several years later, featuring some of the same cast, entitled ''[[Hut 33]]''.{{cite news |work=BBC |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007r8hg |title=BBC Radio 4 — Comedy — Hut 33 |access-date=13 September 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090701091143/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007r8hg |archive-date=1 July 2009 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/3549961.stm |publisher=BBC News |title=Bob Monkhouse's last laugh |date=19 March 2004 |first=Ian |last=Youngs}} * Bletchley came to wider public attention with the documentary series ''[[Station X (TV documentary)|Station X]]'' (1999).{{cite web|url=http://bufvc.ac.uk/dvdfind/index.php/title/20346|title=Station X: The Codebreakers of Bletchley Park|publisher=British Universities Film and Video Council|accessdate=13 October 2018}} * The 2012 ITV programme, ''[[The Bletchley Circle]]'', is a set of murder mysteries set in 1952 and 1953. The protagonists are four female former Bletchley codebreakers, who use their skills to solve crimes. The pilot episode's opening scene was filmed on-site, and the set was asked to remain there for its close adaptation of historiography.{{cite news |last=Hollingshead |first=Iain |title=What happened to the women of Bletchley Park? |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9520807/What-happened-to-the-women-of-Bletchley-Park.html |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location=London |date=4 September 2012 |access-date=3 April 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180809110730/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9520807/What-happened-to-the-women-of-Bletchley-Park.html |archive-date=9 August 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |last=Shaw |first=Malcolm |title=Bletchley Park drama to air on television |url=http://www.itv.com/news/meridian/2012-09-06/bletchley-park-drama-to-air-on-television/ |publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] |accessdate=6 September 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120911162104/http://www.itv.com/news/meridian/2012-09-06/bletchley-park-drama-to-air-on-television/ |archive-date=11 September 2012 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} * [[Ian McEwan]]'s television play ''[[The Imitation Game (play)|The Imitation Game]]'' (1980) concludes at Bletchley Park.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvcream.co.uk/telly/play-for-today/the-imitation-game/|title=The Imitation Game|publisher=TV Cream|accessdate=13 October 2018}} * Bletchley Park was featured in the sixth and final episode of the BBC TV documentary ''[[The Secret War (TV series)|The Secret War]]'' (1977), presented and narrated by William Woodard. This episode featured interviews with Gordon Welchman, [[Harry Golombek]], [[Peter Calvocoressi]], [[F. W. Winterbotham]], Max Newman, Jack Good, and Tommy Flowers.{{cite web|url=https://archivetvmusings.blog/2014/09/14/the-secret-war-1977-bbc-ww2-documentary-simply-media-dvd-review/|title=The Secret War (1977 BBC WW2 documentary)|publisher=Simply Media|accessdate=13 October 2018}} ===Theatre=== * The play ''[[Breaking the Code]]'' (1986) is set at Bletchley Park.{{citation|last=Henry III|first=William A. |title=Ingenuousness And Genius: Breaking The Code| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,966030,00.html| magazine=Time | date= 23 November 1987 |accessdate=10 May revision.text:
'''Charles Carstairs''' (August 1865 – July 1928) was an American [[art dealer]].<ref>Saltzman, 2008, p. 264.</ref> Throughout his career, Carstairs encouraged American clients to invest in European [[Old Master]] paintings.<ref>Saltzman, 2008, p. 170.</ref> He worked closely with industrial magnate [[Henry Clay Frick]], and was responsible for Frick's acquisition of the [[Self Portrait (Frick, Rembrandt)|'Ilchester Rembrandt']] in 1906.<ref>Saltzman, 2008, p. 181</ref> Carstairs also worked with [[Joseph Widener]], an American art collector and founding benefactor of [[National Gallery of Art]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] [[File:Rembrandt Harmensz. van Rijn 130.jpg|thumb|[[Self Portrait (Frick, Rembrandt)|The 'Ilchester Rembrandt']] in the [[Frick Collection]] ]]
==Early life== Carstairs was born in [[Philadelphia]] on August 2, 1865, the 3rd son of James Carstairs and Mary White Carstairs (née Haddock).<ref>Jordan, 1911, p. 874.</ref>
==Career== In 1886, Carstairs began working for his father-in-law (Charles Field Haseltine) at Haseltine Gallery, at 1125 & 1127 Chestnut Street in [[Philadelphia]].<ref>McIntosh, 1997, p. 113.</ref> After working for Haseltine for eight years, Carstairs began working for [[Knoedler|Knoedler & Co.]] in [[New York City]].<ref>McIntosh, 1997, p.113</ref> In 1897, Carstairs was sent to Pittsburgh to lead the newly opened Knoedler & Co. branch at 432 Wood Street. Here, he began promoting [[Old Master]] paintings to Pittsburgh's industrial rich.<ref>Cannadine, 2006, p. 129.</ref> From Pittsburgh, Carstairs moved to [[England]] in 1908 to lead Knoedler's [[London]] branch, which had opened in 1902 at 15 [[Bond Street|Old Bond Street]].<ref>Bailey, 2006, p. 21.</ref><ref>Saltzman, 2008, p. 170.</ref> Carstairs reoriented the London gallery's focus from contemporary Parisian artists to Old Master paintings.<ref>Saltzman, 2008, p. 170.</ref> The outbreak of [[World War I]] interrupted international trade, but also lead to the movement of many Old Master Art works to the United States. This movement of art works was advantageous, both to American dealers such as Knoedler & Co. and collectors such as [[Henry Clay Frick]]. In 1915, Carstairs stated, "England acquired her great Masterpieces during the French Revolution and Napoleonic Wars and now America's opportunity has come." <ref>Saltzman, 2008, p. 242.</ref>
In 1928, upon Roland Knoedler's retirement, Charles Carstairs, his son Carroll Carstairs, Charles Henschel (Knoedler's nephew), and Carmen Mesmore took up the management of the [[Knoedler| Knoedler & Co.]] From this point, Charles Carstairs acted as chairman of the board at Knoedler & Co.<ref>Goldstein, 2000, p. 167</ref>
==Relationship with Henry Clay Frick== Carstairs acted as Frick's preferred dealer for some time. The large quantity of Old Master Paintings in [[Frick Collection|Frick's collection]] demonstrates Carstairs' influence on Frick's taste. In 1908, Frick wrote in a letter to Carstairs "there is no-one whose judgment of the beautiful I have more confidence in than yours".<ref>Bailey, 2006, p. 70.</ref> In his relocation from Pittsburgh to New York, Frick was thrown into an increasingly competitive environment of [[conspicuous consumption]].<ref>Saltzman, 2008, p. 173.</ref> Carstairs turned Frick's attention to increasingly expensive Old Masters paintings as well as artworks that carried social prestige, such as aristocratic portraits, and encouraged Frick to invest in such art as a means of bolstering his reputation.<ref>Saltzman, 2008, p. 163.</ref><ref>Saltzman, 2008, p. 174</ref>
The two remained close friends over Frick's lifetime. Not only did Carstairs aid in the construction of Frick's [[Henry Clay Frick House|East 70th Street mansion]] but he also acted as an honorary [[pallbearer]] at Frick's funeral.<ref>Bailey, 2006, p. 70.</ref>
[[File:Elizabeth Stebbins Carstairs, 1908, by Francois Flameng.jpg|thumb|Elizabeth Stebbins Carstairs, 1908, by Francois Flameng]] ==Personal life== In 1886, Carstairs married Esther Holmes Haseltine (29 April 1864 - 15 January 1907). Carstairs and Haseltine had four children, Charles Haseltine Carstairs (August 1886 – 26 October 1919), [[Carroll Carstairs|Carroll Chevalier Carstairs]] (20 March 1888 – 2 October 1948), James Stewart Carstairs (2 June 1890 – 20 September 1932) and Elizabeth “Lily” Haseltine Carstairs (2 November 1892 – April 1977).<ref>Jordan, 1911, p. 874.</ref>
In 1903 Carstairs met the American actress, Elizabeth Stebbins (19 October 1875 - 7 May 1949), while crossing the Atlantic, he on a buying trip for Knoedler Gallery, and she to perform on the London stage. A romance ensued, and Carstairs divorced his wife, Esther, later that year. He married Elizabeth Stebbins in 1905 and settled in the fashionable Mayfair district of London.<ref>"A Dealer Collects: Reconstructing Charles Stewart Carstairs's Private Art Collection," Journal of the History of Collections, Oxford University Press, April 2016.</ref>
In 1928, shortly after being announced chairman of the board for Knoedler & Co., Charles Carstairs died of a heart attack.<ref>Saltzman, 2008, p. 264.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *Bailey, Colin B., '' Building The Frick Collection: An Introduction to the House and Its Collections'', New York, NY, The Frick Collection, 2006 *Cannadine, David, ''Mellon: An American Life'', New York, NY, Random House Inc., 2006 *Goldstein, Malcolm, ''Landscape with figures: a history of art dealing in the united states'', Oxford, UK, Oxford University Press, 2000 *Jordan, John W., ''Colonial and Revolutionary Families of Pennsylvania, Genealogical and Personal Memoirs'', vol. I, New York, NY, Lewis Historical Pub. Co., 1911 *McIntosh, DeCourcy E., "Demand and Supply: The Pittsburgh Art Trade and M. Knoedler & Co.",''Collecting in the Gilded Age: Art Patronage in Pittsburgh, 1890-1910'', Pittsburgh, PA, Frick Art and Historical Centre, 1997 *Saltzman, Cynthia. ''Old Masters, New World: America's Raid on Europe's Great Pictures, 1880 - World War I'' New York, NY.: Penguin Group (USA) Inc., 2008. *Iacono, Margaret., "A Dealer Collects: Reconstructing Charles Stewart Carstairs's Collection," Journal of the History of Collections, Oxford University Press, April 2016.
==Further reading== *Weisberg, Gabriel, '''Collecting in the Gilded Age: Art Patronage in Pittsburgh, 1890-1910'', Pittsburgh, PA, Frick Art and Historical Centre, 1997 *Reist, Dr. Inge, ''British Models of Art Collecting and the American Response: Reflections Across the Pond'', New York, NY, The Frick Collection, 2014 *{{cite web|url=http://digitalcollections.frick.org/digico/#/archive/Archives/|title=Art Collecting Files of Henry Clay Frick: Frick Collection, Digital Archives|access-date=2017-06-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170427184612/http://digitalcollections.frick.org/digico/#/archive/Archives/#/archive/Archives/|archive-date=2017-04-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Carstairs, Charles}} [[Category:1865 births]] [[Category:1928 deaths]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Philadelphia]] [[Category:American art dealers]] [[Category:Frick Collection]]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Chris Bertish | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_upright = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1974}} | birth_place = | baptised = | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | burial_place = | burial_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = [[Kommetjie]], [[South Africa]] | nationality = South African | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Big wave surfing|Big wave surfer]], [[Standup paddleboarding|stand-up paddleboarder]], adventurer | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | mother = Fran Bertish | father = Keith Bertish | relatives = Conn Bertish
Greg Bertish | family = | callsign = | awards = | website = {{URL|chrisbertish.com}} | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Chris Bertish''' is a South-African-born [[surfing|surfer]], [[standup paddleboarding|stand-up paddleboarder]], adventurer, and [[motivational speaker]]. He won the Mavericks Big Wave Surf contest in 2009. In March 2017 he completed the first solo, unsupported [[Standup paddleboarding|stand-up paddle board]] (SUP) crossing of the [[Atlantic Ocean]]. He did it while supporting charitable organizations. He has also set other SUP world records.{{cite web |url=http://www.sport24.co.za/OtherSport/South-Africa/chris-bertish-completes-first-ever-solo-unsupported-transatlantic-sup-crossing-20170310 |date=March 10, 2017 |publisher=[[News24|Sports24]] |title=South Africa: Chris Bertis completes first ever solo unsupported transatlantic SUP crossing |quote=Bertish personally committed to funding one operation for a child in Africa through Operation Smile for every world record he achieved on this epic Transatlantic journey. And he achieved many of them including a new world record for a 24-hour solo unsupported and unassisted open ocean distance SUP. |accessdate=March 19, 2017}} His efforts moved an obscure sport onto the forefront of many important media outlets.{{efn-ua|An issue of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine ran his picture.{{cite journal |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|volume=189 |number=11|page=10 |date=March 27, 2017 |title=''Digits '''93'''''|quote=Days it took surfer Chris Bertish to travel across the Atlantic on a paddleboad, an unprecedented feat.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.supracer.com/transatlantic-sup-crossing/ |title=Chris Bertish’s Other Atlantic Crossing Record: Making Paddleboarding Front Page News |date=March 14, 2017 |first1=Christopher |last1=Parker |work=SUP Racer |accessdate=March 19, 2017}}}} ==Background== In February 2010, Bertish competed at the [[Mavericks, California|2009/10 Mavericks Surf Contest]] near [[Half Moon Bay, California|Half Moon Bay]], Northern California, winning the [[U.S. Dollars|$]]50,000 big-wave surf competition.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/14/sports/14wave.html |title=13 Hurt When Waves Wash Away Spectators at Contest |date=13 February 2010 |access-date=13 March 2017 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |agency=[[Associated Press]]}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.sport24.co.za/OtherSport/Bertish-wins-at-Mavericks-20100215 |title=Bertish wins at Mavericks |date=15 February 2010 |work=Sports24 |access-date=13 March 2017}} Watched by 50,000 spectators, the contestants experienced waves in excess of {{convert|40|ft|sp=us|abbr=on|0}}. Bertish arrived at the competition without his equipment and had to borrow a board to compete.{{Cite news |url=http://www.sport24.co.za/OtherSport/South-Africa/bertish-recalls-big-wave-madness-20160504 |title=Bertish recalls big wave madness |date=4 May 2016 |publisher=Sports24 |access-date=13 March 2017}} In 2016, a failed attempt at crossing the Atlantic on a stand-up paddleboard occurred. The boat was piloted by Nicholas Jarossay, a French citizen who was rescued a week into his trip.{{efn-ua| One of the [[rudder]] lines failed, skewing the boat sideways to oncoming wind and waves. A large swell flipped the board, which [[Turtling (sailing)|turtled]], and could not be righted (or even towed by the coastal rescuers). A [[Jackline|Safety line]] held him fast to the craft, and [[hypothermia]] soon became a problem. Fortunately, he was rescued. Lack of a self-righting design was a major defect in the attempt.{{cite web |url=http://www.supracer.com/stand-up-paddle-board-atlantic-ocean-crossing-nicolas-jarossay/ |title=The Incredible Story of Nicolas Jarossay’s Abandoned Attempt to Paddle Across the Atlantic Ocean |date=April 14, 2016 |first1=Christopher |last1=Parker |publisher=Supracer.com |accessdate=March 19, 2017}}}} ==Solo Atlantic crossing== In a 93-day trek, Bertish successfully completed a solo, unassisted and unaided crossing of the Atlantic Ocean on a stand up paddle board, going from Morocco to Antigua.{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/03/09/sport/chris-bertish-sup-atlantic-crossing/ |title=World-first as man crosses Atlantic Ocean unaided on paddle board |date=March 9, 2017 |publisher=[[CNN]] |accessdate=March 19, 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/standing-room-only-for-paddle-boarder-who-crossed-atlantic-m9hm3t079 |newspaper=[[The Times]] |title=Standing room only for paddle boarder who crossed Atlantic |first1=Will |last1=Pavia |location=New York |date=March 10, 2017 |accessdate=March 20, 2017}} The feat was the culmination of five years of preparation. On 6 December 2016, Bertish set out from a marina in [[Agadir]], [[Morocco]], in a custom-built {{convert|20|ft|sp=us|abbr=on|0}} stand-up paddle craft on a journey of {{convert|7,400|km|mi}} and 120 days across the [[Atlantic Ocean]] to the Caribbean island of [[Anegada]] in the [[British Virgin Islands]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/07/sports/chris-bertish-paddleboard-crossing-atlantic-ocean.html?action=click&contentCollection=Sports&module=RelatedCoverage®ion=Marginalia&pgtype=article |title=South African Sets Out to Paddle Across the Atlantic |last=Clarke |first=John |date=7 December 2016 |access-date=13 March 2017 |newspaper=The New York Times }}{{cite news |title=Big-Wave Surfer Chris Bertish on his Sup-Transatlantic Crossing: An interview with the man who paddled across an ocean to raise money for charity. |date=March 16, 2017 |first1=Ashtyn |last1=Douglas |url=http://www.surfer.com/features/big-wave-surfer-chris-bertish-on-his-sup-transatlantic-crossing/ |work=[[Surfer Magazine]] |accessdate=March 19, 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://www.si.com/more-sports/2017/03/10/chris-bertish-paddleboard-across-atlantic-ocean-alone |first1=Daniel |last1=Rapaport |date=March 10, 2017 |work=[[Sports Illustrated]] |title=A human man just paddleboarded across the Atlantic Ocean alone |accessdate=March 19, 2017}} His $120,000 craft was designed by [[Phil Morrison (yacht designer)|Phil Morrison]], a [[naval architect]], and resembles a connected row-boat and a stand-up paddle board, called ImpiFish. It weighed {{convert|1,350|lbs|kg}}, which Bertish now considers to have been "too light."{{efn-ua|He normally paddles a S.I.C. Bullet 17 paddleboard, which weighs about {{convert|26|lbs|kg}}. "This weighed about 770 pounds, completely dry. Then there was another 330 pounds of gear, 50 liters of emergency water, and then myself on top of it. It was just really difficult to paddle. But I did so much training with the craft and honestly, after a couple weeks of paddling it, it became my norm and my home." As to the weight, Bertish added: "That sounds heavy ... [but] the craft was much lighter than even the smallest of the boats that have done similar crossings. The craft was probably too light. In the open ocean, you essentially get thrown around like a cork.”}} It had a "number of technological amenities such as a satellite phone, a radar device, a MacBook, a water maker" {{ndash}} carrying the amount of fresh water he needed was impractical.{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/03/stand-up-paddle-board-atlantic-chris-bertish/ |title=Surfer Becomes First to Cross the Atlantic on a Paddleboard |first3=Brian, Photographer |last3=Overfelt |first1=Sarah |last1=Gibbens |first2=Delaney |last2=Chambers |work=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]] |date=March 10, 2017 |accessdate=March 19, 2017}} On 9 March 2017, he arrived in [[Antigua]] at [[English Harbour]] becoming the first person to cross the Atlantic on a stand-up paddle board.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/09/sports/chris-bertish-paddleboard-atlantic-ocean.html |title=Chris Bertish Becomes First to Cross Atlantic by Paddleboard |last=Clarke |first=John |date=9 March 2017 |access-date=13 March 2017 |newspaper=The New York Times }} He made the journey unsupported and unassisted in 93 days. Initially he wanted to continue to Florida, but due to forecasted poor weather made his landfall in Antigua. The craft was self-righting if it [[capsized]], avoiding the possibility of [[Turtling (sailing)|turtling]]. Gear included a [[life raft]], [[flares]], and an emergency [[Bug-out bag|grab bag]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/mar/09/paddleboard-voyage-across-atlantic-completed-in-antigua |title=I'm still standing: paddleboarder makes world-first Atlantic crossing |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=March 9, 2017 |accessdate=March 19, 2017}} An integral part of maintaining stability in adverse weather was the use of [[sea anchor|sea anchors]]. Bertish averaged {{convert|43|mi|km}} a day, surpassing his planned {{convert|30|mi|km}} daily. Paddling was mainly done at night to avoid [[sun exposure]]. The attempt was made in order to raise money for several South African charities to feed, school and provide medical operations for children and succeeded in raising $412,000.{{Cite news |url=http://www.newsmax.com/TheWire/chris-bertish-paddleboard-across-atlantic/2017/03/10/id/778117/ |title=Chris Bertish: Surfer Is First to Paddleboard Across Atlantic Ocean |last=Krausz |first=Jen |date=10 March 2017 |work=[[Newsmax]] |access-date=13 March 2017}} The charities include Signature of Hope Trust, the Lunchbox Foundation and Operation Smile.{{unreliable source|date=March 2017}} The attempt had been sponsored by the financial group [[Carrick Wealth]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thesupcrossing.com/#video |publisher=Chris Bertish |title=The SUP Cross Promotional video |format=Video |accessdate=March 19, 2017}} In addition to gaining the [[Guinness World Record]] for being the first person to cross the Atlantic Ocean on a stand-up paddle board, Bermish also set another world record during the attempt by travelling the furthest distance solo, unsupported and unassisted over open ocean in a day of {{convert|115.86|km|mi}}.{{Cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4301660/Adventurer-42-crosses-Atlantic-PADDLEBOARD.html |title=Adventurer, 42, survives storms and sharks to complete epic 4,050-mile solo voyage across the Atlantic on a PADDLEBOARD |last=Strick |first=Katie |date=11 March 2017 |newspaper=[[The Daily Mail]] |access-date=13 March 2017}}{{unreliable source|date=March 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2697333-south-african-chris-bertish-becomes-1st-to-cross-atlantic-ocean-on-paddleboard |first1=Adam |last1=Wells |title=South African Chris Bertish Becomes 1st to cross Atlantic Ocean on Paddleboard |work=Bleacher report |date=March 10, 2017 |accessdate=March 19, 2017}} In fact, he set at least three world records during the crossing; and promised to pay for a charitable surgery for each of them.{{cite news |url=http://citizen.co.za/news/news-national/1434181/surfer-chris-bertish-breaks-another-world-record-for-charity/ |title=Surfer Chris Bertish breaks another world record for charity |date=February 21, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Citizen (South Africa)|The Citizen]] |accessdate=March 19, 2017}} ==Adventurer== Previously he completed a 3½-day {{Convert|320|km|mi|adj=on}} paddle and a "source to sea" [[Adventure racing|run-paddle-bike]] descent of the [[Thames River]], with an [[English Channel]] SUP bonus crossing.{{cite web |url=http://www.supthemag.com/news/chris-bertish-sets-new-world-record/#RHPrCyDC2mM91Tqe.97 |title=Chris Bertish Sets New World Record |date=January 7, 2014 |first1=Will |last1=Taylor |accessdate=March 19, 2017}} Unofficially and off the South African coast, he set the world record for 12-hour open ocean paddling, covering almost {{convert|130|km|mi}} aided by "great downwind conditions." The previous record was {{convert|120|km|mi}} held by an American. ==Honours== Bertish has been chosen, as one of 100 visionary people, to contributed a 250 word essay to be included in a 3D book.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/sci-tech/2018-02-26-south-african-paddler-to-be-part-of-book-printed-in-space/|title=South African paddler to be part of book printed in space|last=Saal|first=Petru|date=26 February 2018|work=TimesLive (South Africa)|access-date=27 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} The 3D book will be designed by artist [[Ron Arad (industrial designer)|Ron Arad]] and will be a world first and printed in zero gravity. Called, ''Genius: 100 Visions of the Future'', it is organised by the Albert Einstein Foundation Initiative for the Inspired by Einstein Project. ==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist|group=upper-alpha}} ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.thesupcrossing.com/live/ Track Chris Bertish Live Tracker Map] The SUP Crossing. * [http://www.thesupcrossing.com/#video Chris Bertish promotional video] ==See also== *[[Standup paddleboarding]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bertish, Chris}} [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:Big wave surfing]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:South African surfers]] [[Category:Paddleboarders]] [[Category:South African motivational speakers]] [[Category:Guinness World Records]]
